description: Quantify the bias in H0 measurement when using the correct parametric model (Power Law + Peak).
instructions:
1. Download the simulated gravitational wave data from https://zenodo.org/records/13363108
2. Generate or use at least 10 different simulated gravitational wave catalogs
3. Implement the Power Law + Peak model with the same parameters used to generate the data: α = -2.7, mmax = 78 M⊙, mmin = 10 M⊙, μ = 30 M⊙, σ = 7.0 M⊙, fpeak = 0.05
4. For each catalog:
   a. Set up a hierarchical Bayesian inference using Equation 1 from the paper
   b. Infer the posterior distribution of H0 using the Power Law + Peak model
   c. Calculate the posterior mean and standard deviation of H0
   d. Determine if the inferred H0 differs from the true value (67.66 km/s/Mpc) by more than 1σ
5. Calculate the percentage of catalogs for which the Power Law + Peak model produces an over- or under-estimate of H0 at greater than 1σ significance
6. Present the final result as a single float representing the percentage of biased catalogs
output_justification: The paper states on page 9 that the Power Law + Peak model reaches the same level of bias (over- or under-estimate of H0 at greater than 1σ) only 26% of the time, showing a much lower bias rate than the Broken Power Law model.
